VariableDescription.Header:
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     TITLE                           ACE> Electron Proton Alpha Monitor
#     PROJECT                         ACE>Advanced Composition Explorer
#                                     ISTP>International Solar-Terrestrial Physics
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Interplanetary Studies
#     SOURCE_NAME                     AC>Advanced Composition Explorer
#     DATA_TYPE                       H1>5-minute Level 2 data
#     DESCRIPTOR                      EPAM>ACE Electron Proton Alpha Monitor
#     DATA_VERSION                    2
#     GENERATED_BY                    ACE Science Center
#     GENERATION_DATE                 2007127
#     LINK_TEXT                       Release notes and other info available at
#                                     ACE epam data
#     LINK_TITLE                      the ACE Science Center Level 2 Data website
#                                     documentation
#     HTTP_LINK                       http://www.srl.caltech.edu/ACE/ASC/level2/index.html
#                                     http://www.srl.caltech.edu/ACE/ASC/level2/epam_l2desc.html
#     TEXT                            The Electron, Proton, and Alpha Monitor (EPAM) is composed of five
#                                     telescope apertures of three different types.  Two Low Energy
#                                     Foil Spectrometers (LEFS) measure the flux and direction of electrons
#                                     above 30 keV (geometry factor = 0.397 cm2*sr), two Low Energy Magnetic
#                                     Spectrometers (LEMS) measure the flux  and direction of ions greater than 50 keV
#                                     (geometry factor = 0.48 cm2*sr), and the Composition Aperture (CA)
#                                     measures the elemental composition of the ions (geometry factor = 0.24
#                                     cm2*sr). The telescopes use the spin of the spacecraft to sweep the full
#                                     sky. Solid-state detectors are used to measure the energy and composition
#                                     of the incoming particles.
#                                     For more information about the EPAM instrument, visit the EPAM Home Page
#                                     at JHU/APL: http://sd-www.jhuapl.edu/ACE/EPAM/
#                                     The quality of ACE level 2 data is such that it is suitable for serious
#                                     scientific study.  However, to avoid confusion and misunderstanding, it
#                                     is recommended that users consult with the appropriate ACE team members
#                                     before publishing work derived from the data. The ACE team has worked
#                                     hard to ensure that the level 2 data are free from errors, but the team
#                                     cannot accept responsibility for erroneous data, or for misunderstandings
#                                     about how the data may be used. This is especially true if the appropriate
#                                     ACE team members are not consulted before publication. At the very
#                                     least, preprints should be forwarded to the ACE team before publication.
#     MODS                            Initial Public Release 01/28/03 (Version 3)
#                                     11/11/04: Improved metadata (Version 4)
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0327
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 AC_H1_EPA_19970910_V02
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  AC_H1_EPM
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      ACE/EPAM Solar Energetic Particle 5-Minute Level 2 Data
#     PI_NAME                         R. Gold
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  JHU/APL
#     MISSION_GROUP                   ACE
#                                     !___Interplanetary Data near 1 AU
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Particles (space)
#     TIME_RESOLUTION                 5 minute
#     WEB_SITE                        http://www.srl.caltech.edu/ACE/
#     ACKNOWLEDGEMENT                 Please acknowledge the Principal
#                                     Investigator, Dr. Robert Gold of JHU/APL
#     RULES_OF_USE                    See the rules of use available from the ACE
#                                     Science Center at:
#                                     http://www.srl.caltech.edu/ACE/ASC/level2/policy_lvl2.html
#     ALT_LOGICAL_SOURCE              ACE_EPAM_Particles-50-to-1900-keV-Level2-H1_5min_cdf
#
#              ************************************
#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. Time, beginning of interval
#  2. P1 LEMS30 (Low Energy Magnetic Spectrometer; 0.047-0.065 MeV Ions), Sector Avg
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Fri Jan 16 17:30:32 2015

#  2. P1 LEMS30 (Low Energy Magnetic Spectrometer; 0.047-0.065 MeV Ions), Sector Avg
#

dd-mm-yyyy hh:mm:ss.ms    1/(cm**2-s-sr-MeV)
10-09-1997 00:05:00.000              37.6430

#                                     http://www.srl.caltech.edu/ACE/ASC/level2/epam_l2desc.html
#     TEXT                            The Electron, Proton, and Alpha Monitor (EPAM) is composed of five
#                                     telescope apertures of three different types.  Two Low Energy
#                                     Foil Spectrometers (LEFS) measure the flux and direction of electrons
#                                     above 30 keV (geometry factor = 0.397 cm2*sr), two Low Energy Magnetic
#                                     Spectrometers (LEMS) measure the flux  and direction of ions greater than 50 keV
#                                     (geometry factor = 0.48 cm2*sr), and the Composition Aperture (CA)
#                                     measures the elemental composition of the ions (geometry factor = 0.24
#                                     cm2*sr). The telescopes use the spin of the spacecraft to sweep the full
#                                     sky. Solid-state detectors are used to measure the energy and composition
#                                     of the incoming particles.
#                                     For more information about the EPAM instrument, visit the EPAM Home Page
#                                     at JHU/APL: http://sd-www.jhuapl.edu/ACE/EPAM/

#                                     scientific study.  However, to avoid confusion and misunderstanding, it

#                                     ACE team members are not consulted before publication. At the very

#                                     telescope apertures of three different types.  Two Low Energy
